, adjacent to Takeshiba station on the Yurikamome line.  The boat leaves Tokyo each night and arrives at Mikura Island the following morning.  The boat continues to
, returns to Mikura in the afternoon and arrives back in Tokyo in the early evening.

There is little to see or do on the island except to swim with dolphins.  The island has become a major research site for studying dolphins in the wild.  There a numerous boats that take visitors out to the ocean and allow snorkelers to get extremely close to the dolphins.  Scuba diving is not allowed.

value: content=(二郎丸). The oldest guesthouse in Mikura island. It is a traditional Japanese house with
rooms, so guests sleep on futons on the floor. The food is usually Japanese food such as sashimi, tempura or soba with special ingredients from the island such as the spicy endemic
plant and fresh fish from the sea around Mikura, but if there is need, Western food can also be cooked. The staff there can speak English @yen;6500 (including food).
